awd_titl_txt: Dynamics and Evolution of Virus and Immune Response Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This research develops new mathematical and computational methods to understand the competition between evolving viruses (like HIV) and the immune system, which seeks to eradicate them.  The dynamics of virus and immune response within an infected host can be viewed as a complex ecosystem.  During HIV infection, an extensive repertoire of immune cells target the virus, while HIV can rapidly evolve resistance to multiple immune responses.   The ensuing battle precipitates a dynamic network of interacting viral strains and immune response variants.   Understanding the main factors shaping viral resistance pathways and immune dynamics is crucial for designing effective vaccines and immunotherapies.  Mathematical modeling can help elucidate patterns of viral escape from immune attack, however overall system complexity challenges the analysis of such models.  This project develops mathematical models and analytical techniques for understanding the dynamics of multiple virus and immune response populations within infected hosts.  This research uses dynamical systems and computational methods to characterize persistent structures of the evolving virus-immune response network.   Potential HIV vaccine and treatment strategies will be investigated utilizing the mathematical models.  Furthermore, the models will be connected to Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV) data in collaboration with biologists.   Also significant are the educational impacts arising from the interdisciplinary training of graduate and undergraduate students in this research project.

Rapidly evolving pathogens, such as SIV and HIV, can evade the host immune responses via mutations at several targeted epitopes (viral proteins).  The concurrent interaction of diverse virus and immune populations necessitate considering a complex system in order to understand viral escape at multiple epitopes.  This project develops and analyzes mathematical models for virus and immune response variants interacting in a network.  Stability and persistence of viral/immune populations will be characterized in terms of threshold quantities and the structure of the underlying interaction network.   An important question is to determine what mechanisms cause the virus to win this battle in most drug-naive HIV infected patients, and alternatively what leads to long-term viral control in a small percentage of drug-naive HIV infected individuals known as Elite Controllers.  Results from the differential equation models and stochastic counterparts will inform upon viral escape of immune response at multiple epitopes, along with the more complex scenario of virus-antibody coevolution.   From a broader perspective, the methods will be applicable to other predator-prey ecological networks, for example phage-bacteria communities.  Extensions relevant to HIV biology, such as incorporating heterogeneous immune recognition kinetics during the infected cell lifecycle, latent cell infection and different vaccine/immunotherapy strategies, will be investigated.   Results will be linked to data, in particular through interdisciplinary collaboration connecting the models with viral genomic and immune cell data from SIV infection experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Integrating the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of rapidly evolving pathogens presents a challenging problem in mathematical biology.    For example, during HIV infection, the virus can escape several immune response populations via resistance mutations at distinct epitopes (proteins coded in viral genome), precipitating a dynamic network of interacting virus and immune variants.  Understanding the main factors shaping viral resistance pathways and immune dynamics is crucial for designing effective vaccines and immunotherapies.  The dynamics of virus and immune response within an infected host can be viewed as a complex ecosystem.  This project developed formulation, analysis and simulation of general multi-strain ecosystem models, which may represent a complex assemblage of interacting multiple virus and/or immune populations.  The results connect which mutant viral strains evolve and persist to the underlying viral fitness landscape, while accounting for the multiple immune responses triggered within the host.  Furthermore, we produced a flexible computational framework for modeling pathogen adaption to its environment, and incorporated population genetics and census data from SIV/immune response experiments and the cholera outbreak in Haiti to gain insight on potential control strategies.  


Through mathematical analysis of the models, we show that that long term dynamics of viral mutants evolving resistance at distinct epitopes (viral proteins targeted by immune responses) are governed by evolutionary genetics measures on how mutations affect the inherent fitnesses of viral strains.  This leads to simplifying rules for virus-immune community evolution, providing insight on potential immunotherapy strategies and a foundation for connecting ecological network dynamics with evolutionary genetics.  For example, we prove that the virus evolves along its most favorable pathway developing resistance to the strongest immune responses in order if combinations of mutations are more favorable than would be expected by single mutation outcomes.  In interdisciplinary projects, we leveraged genetic and census data with phylodynamic inference and eco-evolutionary models to recapitulate dynamic genetic diversity shedding light on evolutionaryforces in SIV-immune response experiments and the cholera outbreak in Haiti.   The cholera model fit both observed case counts and pathogen effective population size (genetic diversity) only when environmental replication outside hosts is incorporated.  The model mimicked observed cholera adaptations to environment and simulations found that vaccination efforts were complicated by this in Haiti, along with suggesting water-source interventions in combination with vaccination.   Each of these studies appear as publications in high impact interdisciplinary scientific and mathematical biology journals. 

 The training of three graduate students and three undergraduate students funded as research assistants was among the broader impacts of the project.  The downstream successes on development of these young scientists were evident, including publications and research conference talks which helped bolster their records leading to postdoctoral job opportunities. In addition to disseminating results in articles, the grant participants have reached a broad audience through giving talks about the research at conferences, seminars, and public events, along with interviews for university media, in order to convey gained scientific ideas and demonstrate the application of mathematical modeling to infectious diseases and the life and social sciences in general.
